  On 5/27/06, Barry Thomas <warlord@...> wrote:
  >
  > Blokes,
  >
  > The story I remember is that menuki are vestigial ornaments from pre-Heian
  > times
  > when the tsuka was fixed to the nakago with a rivet that was not
  > removable.  The
  > heads of the rivet were decorated and eventually became the menuki we know
  > today.  What I did not know until these emails is that some menuki have
  > "interlocking pins" to become mekugi.  Sure, I've seen these on cheap
  > Meiji
  > pieces, especially tanto, but didn't know early Goto menuki had the same
  > feature.  We can clearly see that as the Nihonto developed from earliest
  > times
  > the disadvantage of a fixed rivet became evident, but the early menuki
  > discussed
  > appear to have still functioned as a mekugi, only later becoming separate
  > with a
  > bamboo mekugi, or mekugi of other material (iron??).  I also remember that
  > in
  > the Momoyama period a single menuki was used, accounting for some of the
  > "orphans" we see.  Looking back over my collecting career I think I once
  > had a
  > single (i.e., never a pair) shakudo menuki of a pomegranate.  It was of
  > that
  > really dark black shakudo.  Sometimes knowledge comes too late to save us
  > from
  > ourselves!!!
  >
  > Ken, I do have somewhere a late 19th century English treatise on the Goto
  > mainline (Shirobei 17 generations) with photos, but it doesn't go into the
  > "secret marks"...  Does anyone know the title of the Japanese one that Ken
  > mentions??
  >
  > Regards,
  >
  > Barry Thomas.
